section.title: It's time, I'd rather, I'd better
section.sectiontitle: Use the form It's time + subject + past tense to mean 'I / you / he, etc., should have done something already or at least started it'.

section.title: It's time, I'd rather, I'd better
section.sectiontitle: We use the form subject + would rather + object + past tense (+ than ...) to talk about what we'd prefer someone else to do.
section.text1a: I'd rather you didn't talk about money right now.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the form subject + would rather + infinitive (+ than ...) to talk about what you'd prefer to do.
section.text3a: I'd rather go to the beach than go shopping.
section.text4a: Would you rather go to the cinema or get a video out?

section.title: It's time, I'd rather, I'd better
section.sectiontitle: We use the form subject + had better + infinitive to talk about something when it is advisable to do it (in the present or future).
section.text1a: I'd better mend that window before it starts raining.
section.text2a: We'd better slow down – there's ice on the road.
